nodes.text: A decision tree classifier (J48/C4.5) can effectively predict diabetes status from the Pima Indian dataset
We applied the J48 decision tree implementation in WEKA to build a predictive model for diabetes
Dataset: Pima Indian Diabetes dataset of 768 female patients with 8 predictor variables and a binary class (tested_positive or tested_negative)
WEKA J48 method: builds C4.5-style decision trees using normalized information gain, handles continuous and discrete attributes, missing values, and offers pruning
Entropy of class distribution computed as 0.9328 (entropy(class) = 0.9328)
Information gain for Plasma glucose attribute = 0.1332, the highest gain reported and selected as root split
Confusion matrix counts: True Positive = 468, True Negative = 178, False Positive = 32, False Negative = 90
Compared to an existing method, the proposed method improved accuracy by 0.48 percentage points but increased model build time by 0.02 seconds
Computed information gains for other attributes: BMI gain = 0.0724, Pregnancy gain = 0.0366 (lower than Plasma)
Dataset limitation: several attributes contain zero values interpreted as missing (e.g., glucose=0 for 5 patients, BMI=0 for 11, blood pressure=0 for 28, skin fold=0 for 192, insulin=0 for 140)
Removing records with missing values reduced the dataset to 392 cases (103 positive, 262 negative), altering class counts and available training data
Decision tree induction principle used: at each node the attribute with highest information gain is chosen to partition instances
Context: Classification and prediction are common data mining tasks used to build models that predict disease status from medical diagnostic features
Assumption: the first eight variables are sufficient predictors to infer the ninth class variable (diabetes test outcome)
Conclusion: J48 in WEKA yields a reasonably accurate diabetes prediction model (84.11%) but handling missing values is necessary to improve exactness and reliability
